instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I got a water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that doesn't boot up. It has a green light on the charger (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57v , <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 17.08v, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.46v) and 3.42v on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> pads. After doing some visual inspection I noticed that that the FireWire port power switch circuitry is f*cked. Its missing <TRANSISTOR>Q4262</TRANSISTOR> & F4260. Would this circuitry prevent the computer from booting up? From what I can see, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> are missing. Should the s3 state be present when the computer is off?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Don't care about firewire unless shit is shorted. This board should turn itself on after power is connected. First check <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> again if it is not pulsing briefly after connecting power. Then check RTC 3V to <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>-1803

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2223"]Don't care about firewire unless shit is shorted. This board should turn itself on after power is connected. First check <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> again if it is not pulsing briefly after connecting power. Then check RTC 3V to <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>-1803[/QUOTE]

Thanks duke!! I have re-checked <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and its shorted to ground. I tried injecting some voltage (no more than 3v) into this line but it's hard to determine the faulty component since it only consumes 0.18A at 3.0v. I noticed that is getting a little bit warm <CHIP>U4800</CHIP>. Should I add more voltage? Any recommendations? Thanks!

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have managed to remove the short by removing <CHIP>U4800</CHIP> but now when I connect the charger to the computer, the short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> appears again and then disappears. Please note that I haven't replaced this chip. Is this chip important? From what I can see it's usb peripheral controller chip . Thanks for all the help

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4800</CHIP> is not needed. <CHIP>U4800</CHIP> will only fry when the 5V bus has been high. There will be more components dead that are on this bus usually the ISL chips that get their 5V from this bus.
And no the short does not appear again, you are measuring when there is still some voltage left or measuring when powered on even!

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2254"]<CHIP>U4800</CHIP> is not needed. <CHIP>U4800</CHIP> will only fry when the 5V bus has been high. There will be more components dead that are on this bus usually the ISL chips that get their 5V from this bus.
And no the short does not appear again, you are measuring when there is still some voltage left or measuring when powered on even![/QUOTE]

Thanks for the clarification duke!! At the moment my board is missing <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and this line is not shorted to ground. My Meter on diode mode with red probe on gnd and red probe on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> gives me 0.430 I tried to see to see if the computer would turn on  by injecting 5v into this line. When I did this the fan spinned for a second and my PSU got stuck at 0.24A and 5v. Not sure what's going on here. Is my <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> fried?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What voltages are coming on? I bet you are not getting <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, measure all coils and see which ones are coming on. They may be pulsing very short so check carefully.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2296"]What voltages are coming on? I bet you are not getting <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, measure all coils and see which ones are coming on. They may be pulsing very short so check carefully.[/QUOTE]

Should I measure it when I'm inject 5v into <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2326"]No, just normal[/QUOTE]

hello duke, you are correct I'm also missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. I'm a little bit confused thou! Hopefully you can clear up some things. At the moment I don't have <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>. I tried injecting 5v into this line to see if the computer starts up and it consumes 0.24amps. I noticed that <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is getting really warm when this occurs. I don't understand why there is a consumption on this line if I already removed the short on this line. Any idea? I have proceeded with troubleshooting this ic and I'm getting the following values  ENTRIP1 0v, EN0 1.71v, ENTRIP2 0.62v, PGOOD 0.13v, VIN 12.57v . Do you think my <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is no good? I checked <SIGNAL>P5VS3EN_L</SIGNAL> on point 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and I have 2.26v. Does this mean my mosfet is not good? According to the schematics it looks like <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> uses the same mosfet to generate entrip1&2. Please correct me if this is wrongThanks!

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I had the same problem with this board I had no <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and it was because of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> that was shorted. And as I can see you have the same problem, I would replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
but wait for what Duke says

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sorry duke! I couldnt control myself. It seems that <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> was shorted. When i removed this ic i was able to inject no more than 3 v into this line without any consumption. I think ill Be able to restore <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> after replacing this chip. If this is the case ill be a happy guy. Can i salvage this chip from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, it is the same chip [FONT=Helvetica]<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>[/FONT]

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do keep in mind that core 2 duo <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards have different orientation on <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> than core i5/i7 boards.

So don't rip it off the 2879 and directly transfer it to the 3115, it will go on fire. make sure you put it back in the proper orientation.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: GOOD NEWS!!! After replacing <CHIP>TPS51121</CHIP> with a donor ic and injecting the 5v into <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>  we have a spinning fan. It's time to find out why  I'm missing that voltage. Any idea? If I'm not mistaken this line gets created by <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> so this should have addressed this issue. I think my <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> is not opening since is getting 2.26v at the gate.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What's the voltage on pin 6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 2447"]What's the voltage on pin 6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?[/QUOTE]

 Hey Louis, here are my readings for <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> VIN 12.57v, EN0 2.98v, ENTRIP1 0v, ENTRIP2 0.85v PGOOD 0v. Ilex me know if you need any other ones. I have recently changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> but no luck. Thanks for giving me a hand

23 continuity to gnd
